unnormalised: Folks, there's been a bit of a kerfuffle online about LaTeX equations looking wonky on some platforms. Apparently, folks are saying that when you copy-paste from a doc into, say, a Reddit comment or a forum, symbols are getting mangled. Like, your beautiful `\frac{1}{2}` is turning into something totally unreadable. Ugh, the worst! I saw one person post their equation: `E=mc^2` and it just showed up as E=mc2 plain text.
normalised: Folks, there's been a bit of a kerfuffle online about L-A-T-e-X equations looking wonky on some platforms. Apparently, folks are saying that when you copy-paste from a doc into, say, a Reddit comment or a forum, symbols are getting mangled. Like, your beautiful fraction one divided by two is turning into something totally unreadable. Ugh, the worst! I saw one person post their equation: E equals m c squared and it just showed up as E equals m c two plain text.

unnormalised: The problem seems to be the lack of proper rendering support on different websites. So, if someone's using LaTeX to type up a really complex equation, like maybe the quadratic formula `x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}`, copying that into, say, Twitter? Forget about it! It will just become a hot mess. No one wants to see `-b +- sqrt(b2 - 4ac) / 2a`. This is causing a lot of headaches for students and researchers alike.

This is causing a lot of headaches for students and researchers alike.

unnormalised: The workaround? Either take a screenshot of the equation or use a proper LaTeX editor online and then copy the rendered image. Slow, but hey, it's better than nothing. Someone even suggested a browser extension! What are your thoughts? Is `\int_a^b f(x) dx` just a dream on the internet?
